page.title: 14Wild Flowers in Cattistock
page.content: Wild flowers abound; in springtime snowdrops are massed in the woods, followed by bluebells, which form a carpet under the trees. Primroses are increasing, cowslips are decreasing and stunted; violets, aconites and wood anemones are scarce. In early summer road sides are white with cow parsley, yarrow and meadowsweet. Wild iris and marsh marigolds grow in the boggy areas near the river. On the chalk downland rare orchids are regularly seen. The many species of wild flowers - and garden flowers - support a great variety of butterflies. As well as the more common Peacocks, Tortoiseshells and Red Admirals, 1985 has been a good year for the Common Blue and Chalkhill Blue butterflies. The Cinnabar Moth is also very common in the area.
